title: Be The XXInventor
challengeText: Your challenge will be to invent a machine to haul logs out of the forest! For each of the five challenges, drag and drop your best guess from the options to the Lombard Hauler.

title: 1. The Power Challenge
challengeText: Lumbermen used horses to haul timber from the forest to the nearest river or railroad. This work was very hard on the horses. Horses couldn't pull a heavy logging sled more than a few miles while lumbermen needed to go deeper into the woods to harvest the logs. What power source do you think would work better?

options.label: Oxen
options.feedback: Sorry, incorrect! Oxen are tougher and stronger than horses however, oxen are very slow so they weren't suitable. Try a different solution.

options.label: Steam Tractor
options.feedback: Excellent solution! Steam worked! A steam powered machine could haul much further than a team of horses, and it didnâ€™t get tired or hungry. Let's call our new machine a Lombard Log Hauler! Onward to the next challenge!

options.label: Electric Trolley
options.feedback: Sorry, incorrect! Alvin Lombard actually tried electricity to power a Lombard Log Hauler. It operated very much like a trolley car. However, it was deemed a failure due to the cost. Try a different solution.

title: 2. The Traction Challenge
challengeText: Timber was usually moved during the winter when the ground was frozen and sleds could easily be hauled over icey and snowy roads. However, designing a machine that could move under those wintery conditions was rather tricky. What solution would provide the right traction?

options.label: Crawler Tracks
options.feedback: Right you are! In 1900 Alvin Lombard developed and patented the first practical crawler track system. Crawler tracks spread the weight of the machine so it can move over soft ground and have plenty of traction on ice and snow.

options.label: Large Wheels
options.feedback: Wheels would sink in snow and soft ground and the steel wheels of the day offered very little traction on ice and snow.

options.label: Giant Screws
options.feedback: Interesting solution! In 1904 Ira Peavey of Bangor, Maine patented a "Snow Locomotive" which used giant screws to move it through the snow and over ice. Unfortunately, it worked but was not a complete success.
